abstract.text: Provide quick access to useful actions by adding menus and keyboard shortcuts to your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Adding menus and shortcuts to the menu bar and user interface

inlineContent.text: This sample project demonstrates how to add menu commands and keyboard shortcuts to the menu bar. The sample app uses its
object to insert a
object that adds the following menus:
New: Appears at the beginning of the File menu and contains the two operations New Date Item and New Text Item, which add items to the table view.
Cities: Contains a group of UICommand and UIKeyCommand objects.
Navigation: Contains a group of UIKeyCommand objects for command-key navigation.
Style: Contains a group of UICommand objects that have checkmark states. This grouping looks like a font-style menu for text formatting.
Tools: Contains a group of UICommand objects.
The sample project also shows you how to add contextual menus to views, and how to handle menu-command selection using
In Xcode, select your development team on the iOS targetâ€™s Signing and Capabilities tab.

content.text: Add menus to the menu bar

inlineContent.text: Create

objects and use them to construct the menus and submenus. This sample adds menus to the menu bar when it runs on macOS, and key command elements in those menus also appear in the discoverability heads-up display (HUD) on iPad when the user presses the command key.
The Mac version of an iPad app comes with a standard menu bar. Use the
class, an object that represents the main or contextual menu system, to modify the menu bar.
The sample uses

object that the sample then uses to add and remove menus. Because menus can exist with no window or view hierarchy, the system only consults

This sample inserts the Open command into the middle of the menu barâ€™s File menu:

Mac apps also typically include a Print menu command in the File menu. This sample includes both Print and Export as PDF menu commands in the File Menu. These menu commands are automatically inserted when the

Editing operations, such as cut, copy, paste, and delete, are commonly used in most apps. This sample app provides these operations through the Edit menu, where the user can edit the sampleâ€™s left-side content or its primary table-view content. These operations represent the first-responder functions
This sample implements
to determine if these edit operations are supported.

content.text: Add commands to control the user interface

The sample also demonstrates how to add menu commands as command-key equivalents. The following example shows how to create a menu with all four arrow keys as command keys:

For macOS, the user control-clicks or right-clicks the

The sample uses
to display Cut, Copy, Paste, Delete, Rename, and Share commands. This kind of contextual menu is a grouping of
objects.

inlineContent.text: Mac apps typically display app-specific preferences using a preferences window. The sample adds a preferences window by adding a Settings bundle to the Xcode projectâ€™s target. The window automatically becomes available to the user through the Preferences menu command in the Application menu. To learn more about preferences, see

abstract.text: Returns a localized version of a string from the default table, which Xcode autogenerates when exporting localizations.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A menu element that performs its action in a closure.
A menu element that performs its action in a selector.
An interaction object that you use to display relevant actions for your content.
The methods for providing the set of actions to perform on your content, and for customizing the preview of that content.
Returns the source view to use when animating the appearance of the preview interface.
A continuous gesture recognizer that interprets pointer movement over a view.
An object that specifies a key press perform on a hardware keyboard and the resulting action.
An interface for adding and removing menus from a menu system.
An object representing a main or contextual menu system.
The main menu system.
Asks the receiving responder to add and remove items from a menu system.
Asks the receiving responder to validate the command.
Provide a Preferences window in your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst so users can manage app preferences defined in a Settings bundle.
Detect when someone presses and releases keys on a physical keyboard.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Handling key presses made on a physical keyboard

abstract.text: Create a version of your iPad app that users can run on a Mac device.
Simplify interactions with your app using menu systems, contextual menus, Home Screen quick actions, and keyboard shortcuts.
Navigate between user interface elements using a keyboard and focusable UI elements in iPad apps and apps built with Mac Catalyst.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Navigating an appâ€™s user interface using a keyboard
